The 'Allied invasion of Sicily', codenamed 'Operation Husky', was a major World
War II campaign, in which the Allies took Sicily from the Axis (Italy and Nazi
Germany). It was a large scale amphibious and airborne operation, followed by
six weeks of land combat. It launched the Italian Campaign.

Husky began on the night of 9â10 July 1943, and ended 17 August. Strategically,
Husky achieved the goals set out for it by Allied planners. The Allies drove
Axis air, land and naval forces from the island; the Mediterranean's sea lanes
were opened and Italian dictator Benito Mussolini was toppled from power. It
opened the way to the Allied invasion of Italy.
